question: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at term, and pregnancy was complicated by prolonged labor. There is no family history of serious illness. He can sit upright without support and can roll over from the prone to the supine position. He cannot pull himself to stand. He can grasp his rattle and cannot transfer it from one hand to the other. He babbles. He cries if anyone apart from his parents holds him or plays with him. He touches his own reflection in the mirror. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is at 40th percentile for head circumference, 30th percentile for length and at 40th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following developmental milestones is delayed in this infant?
prompt:
A 6-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at term, and pregnancy was complicated by prolonged labor. There is no family history of serious illness. He can sit upright without support and can roll over from the prone to the supine position. He cannot pull himself to stand. He can grasp his rattle and cannot transfer it from one hand to the other. He babbles. He cries if anyone apart from his parents holds him or plays with him. He touches his own reflection in the mirror. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is at 40th percentile for head circumference, 30th percentile for length and at 40th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following developmental milestones is delayed in this infant?A)Fine motor
B)Social
C)Gross motor
D)Cognitive
output0: The fine motor skills of the infant are delayed. The infant has difficulty transferring the rattle from one hand to the other, which is a sign of fine motor delay.
output1: The delayed developmental milestone in this infant is social. Although the infant can hold his rattle and grasp it, he cries when anyone apart from his parents holds him or plays with him. This indicates that the infant has difficulty with social interaction and attachment, which is a common delay in infants who have experienced prolonged labor during birth.
output2: The gross motor milestone of pulling oneself to stand is delayed in this infant. Although the infant can sit upright without support and roll over, he cannot pull himself to stand, which is a skill that is typically acquired by this age.
output3: The cognitive development of a 6-month-old infant is delayed in this case. The infant's inability to transfer a toy from one hand to the other and his lack of interest in playing with anyone other than his parents indicates a delay in cognitive development.

question: A 52-year-old man without concomitant diseases, went to the emergency room for manes of 24 hours of evolution without hemodynamic repercussion. Denies non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. The hematocrit is 33% and the rest of the analytical is normal. The upper digestive endoscopy performed urgently at 6 hours after admission shows a normal stomach, without blood or blood remnants and an 8 mm diameter ulcer excavated on the anterior face of the duodenal bulb with "visible vessel" at its base and without bleeding active. Which of the following statements is true?
correct_answer: In the initial endoscopy it is indicated to apply an endoscopic therapy and later to establish intravenous treatment with high doses of a proton pump inhibitor. This strategy has been shown to reduce the risk of hemorrhagic recurrence and mortality.
options: A)In the initial endoscopy it is indicated to apply an endoscopic therapy and later to establish intravenous treatment with high doses of a proton pump inhibitor. This strategy has been shown to reduce the risk of hemorrhagic recurrence and mortality.

B)In the initial endoscopy, given the absence of active bleeding, endoscopic therapy is not indicated. Subsequently, to reduce the risk of hemorrhagic recurrence, intravenous treatment should be instituted with high doses of a proton pump inhibitor.

C)In the initial endoscopy it is indicated to apply an endoscopic therapy. It has not been possible to demonstrate that to subsequently institute intravenous treatment with high doses of a proton pump inhibitor provides any additional benefit.
D)Given that it is a complicated ulcer (hemorrhage), the best therapeutic option once the hemorrhagic episode is resolved is a vagotomy and pyloroplasty.
prompt:
A 52-year-old man without concomitant diseases, went to the emergency room for manes of 24 hours of evolution without hemodynamic repercussion. Denies non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. The hematocrit is 33% and the rest of the analytical is normal. The upper digestive endoscopy performed urgently at 6 hours after admission shows a normal stomach, without blood or blood remnants and an 8 mm diameter ulcer excavated on the anterior face of the duodenal bulb with "visible vessel" at its base and without bleeding active. Which of the following statements is true?A)In the initial endoscopy it is indicated to apply an endoscopic therapy and later to establish intravenous treatment with high doses of a proton pump inhibitor. This strategy has been shown to reduce the risk of hemorrhagic recurrence and mortality.
B)In the initial endoscopy, given the absence of active bleeding, endoscopic therapy is not indicated. Subsequently, to reduce the risk of hemorrhagic recurrence, intravenous treatment should be instituted with high doses of a proton pump inhibitor.
C)In the initial endoscopy it is indicated to apply an endoscopic therapy. It has not been possible to demonstrate that to subsequently institute intravenous treatment with high doses of a proton pump inhibitor provides any additional benefit.
D)Given that it is a complicated ulcer (hemorrhage), the best therapeutic option once the hemorrhagic episode is resolved is a vagotomy and pyloroplasty.
output0: The correct answer is A)In the initial endoscopy it is indicated to apply an endoscopic therapy and later to establish intravenous treatment with high doses of a proton pump inhibitor. This strategy has been shown to reduce the risk of hemorrhagic recurrence and mortality.
output1: In the case of an ulcerated duodenal bulb, the initial endoscopy should not include endoscopic therapy, as there is no active bleeding. The best therapeutic approach is to institute intravenous treatment with high doses of a proton pump inhibitor, as this has been shown to reduce the risk of hemorrhagic recurrence and mortality.
output2: In the case of an 8 mm duodenal ulcer with a visible vessel at its base, endoscopic therapy is indicated. However, there is no evidence to support the use of high doses of proton pump inhibitors as a preventive measure for recurrent hemorrhage.
output3: Option D is the best answer because the patient has a complicated ulcer (hemorrhage) and the best therapeutic option once the hemorrhagic episode is resolved is a vagotomy and pyloroplasty. This is a surgical procedure that can help to prevent further bleeding and promote healing.

question: Most common site of colorectal carcinoma is -
prompt:
Most common site of colorectal carcinoma is -A)Rectum
B)Sigmoid Colon
C)Ascending Colon
D)Descending Colon
output0: The most common site of colorectal carcinoma is the rectum, followed by the sigmoid colon. The ascending colon, descending colon, and transverse colon are less commonly affected.
output1: The sigmoid colon is the most common site of colorectal carcinoma because it is the part of the colon that is closest to the rectum and has a higher risk of developing cancer due to its slower blood flow and increased exposure to toxins.
output2: The ascending colon is the most common site of colorectal carcinoma because it is the most exposed to the colonic mucosa, which is the most susceptible to carcinogenic substances.
output3: The descending colon is the most common site of colorectal carcinoma. This is because the descending colon is the longest part of the colon and is more prone to developing cancer due to its longer exposure to carcinogens.

question: A 70-year-old man presents with cough and progressively worsening shortness of breath for the last 6 months. He feels short of breath even without exertion and states he ‘got winded’ while walking to his bedroom last night. He describes his cough as non-productive and says he can identify no recognizable triggers. No significant past medical history. The patient is a retired welder and has been living with his son since his wife passed away 5 years ago. He denies any smoking history or current alcohol or drug use. His vital signs include: pulse rate 72/min, respiratory rate 15/min, blood pressure 134/80 mm Hg, and temperature 36.8°C (98.0°F). On physical examination, digital clubbing is noted. Bilateral basilar fine crackles on noted on pulmonary auscultation. Expiratory flow rates are measured and found to be high when corrected for lung volume. A chest X-ray is performed and shown in the image below. Which of the following most likely accounts for the increased expiratory flow rate in this patient?
prompt:
A 70-year-old man presents with cough and progressively worsening shortness of breath for the last 6 months. He feels short of breath even without exertion and states he ‘got winded’ while walking to his bedroom last night. He describes his cough as non-productive and says he can identify no recognizable triggers. No significant past medical history. The patient is a retired welder and has been living with his son since his wife passed away 5 years ago. He denies any smoking history or current alcohol or drug use. His vital signs include: pulse rate 72/min, respiratory rate 15/min, blood pressure 134/80 mm Hg, and temperature 36.8°C (98.0°F). On physical examination, digital clubbing is noted. Bilateral basilar fine crackles on noted on pulmonary auscultation. Expiratory flow rates are measured and found to be high when corrected for lung volume. A chest X-ray is performed and shown in the image below. Which of the following most likely accounts for the increased expiratory flow rate in this patient?A)Anatomical dead space
B)Lung compliance
C)Radial traction on airway wall
D)Small airway wall thickness
output0: The increased expiratory flow rate in this patient is most likely due to anatomical dead space. The chest X-ray shows digital clubbing, which is a sign of chronic bronchitis. The patient's history of progressive shortness of breath and cough, along with the presence of bilateral basilar fine crackles on pulmonary auscultation, are also consistent with chronic bronchitis. Anatomical dead space is a common feature of chronic bronchitis and can lead to increased expiratory flow rates.
output1: The increased expiratory flow rate in this patient is most likely due to lung compliance. Lung compliance is the ability of the lungs to expand and fill with air. In this patient, the chest X-ray shows bilateral basilar fine crackles, which are consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). COPD causes the airways to become narrow and obstructed, making it harder for the lungs to expand and fill with air. As a result, the lungs become less compliant, which can lead to increased expiratory flow rates.
output2: The patient's chest X-ray shows a characteristic "halo" sign, which is indicative of radial traction on the airway walls. This is a common finding in patients with chronic bronchitis and emphysema, as the airways are narrowed and the walls are pushed inward by the increased pressure. As a result, the patient experiences increased expiratory flow rates due to the resistance in the airways.
output3: The increased expiratory flow rate in this patient is most likely due to small airway wall thickness. This can be seen on the chest X-ray, which shows a characteristic "spider-like" appearance of the small airways. This is consistent with the patient's history of smoking, which can cause chronic inflammation and narrowing of the small airways.

question: A 76-year-old female is brought to the emergency department for altered mental status. She is accompanied by a nurse from her nursing home. The nurse says that usually the patient is interactive even though she is sometimes forgetful. In the last two days, the patient has been increasingly lethargic and doesn’t respond to the staff’s questions. She also has not been able to get up and use the restroom so the staff has had to change multiple soiled sheets. Her temperature is 102.1°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 100/74 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 24/min. The patient is combative on arrival but can be subdued with reorientation by the care team. She is not oriented to person, place, or time. Urinalysis shows positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Urine culture grows >100,000 CFU of E. coli. The physician team would like to consent this patient for a Foley catheter. Which of the following is the best assessment of the patient’s capacity to make healthcare decisions?
correct_answer: Capacity cannot be determined at this time
options: A)The patient does not have capacity to make decisions
B)The patient does have capacity to make decisions
C)The hospital ethics board should be consulted
D)Capacity cannot be determined at this time
prompt:
A 76-year-old female is brought to the emergency department for altered mental status. She is accompanied by a nurse from her nursing home. The nurse says that usually the patient is interactive even though she is sometimes forgetful. In the last two days, the patient has been increasingly lethargic and doesn’t respond to the staff’s questions. She also has not been able to get up and use the restroom so the staff has had to change multiple soiled sheets. Her temperature is 102.1°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 100/74 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 24/min. The patient is combative on arrival but can be subdued with reorientation by the care team. She is not oriented to person, place, or time. Urinalysis shows positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Urine culture grows >100,000 CFU of E. coli. The physician team would like to consent this patient for a Foley catheter. Which of the following is the best assessment of the patient’s capacity to make healthcare decisions?A)The patient does not have capacity to make decisions
B)The patient does have capacity to make decisions
C)The hospital ethics board should be consulted
D)Capacity cannot be determined at this time
output0: The patient’s altered mental status, lethargy, and inability to respond to staff questions suggest that she may not have the capacity to make healthcare decisions. Additionally, the fact that she is combative and cannot be oriented to person, place, or time further supports the assessment that she does not have capacity.
output1: Although the patient is elderly and has altered mental status, the fact that she is combative and can be reoriented suggests that she has the capacity to make decisions. Additionally, the patient’s history of being interactive and sometimes forgetful suggests that she has the ability to make decisions, even if she is not always able to do so.
output2: The patient's altered mental status, lethargy, and incontinence suggest a possible dementia or delirium, which can affect their ability to make informed healthcare decisions. Therefore, the hospital ethics board should be consulted to assess the patient's capacity to make decisions and to determine the appropriate course of action.
output3: Capacity to make healthcare decisions cannot be determined at this time because the patient is altered and not oriented to person, place, or time. Additionally, the patient is combative and has a history of forgetfulness, which suggests that they may not be able to fully understand the information and make informed decisions. The hospital ethics board should be consulted to determine the best course of action.

question: Question linked to image nº18 A 61-year-old man with a nephrotic syndrome with hypertension of 160/90 mmHg and preserved renal function. Analytically, it highlights a glomerular filtration rate (GFR) of 50 mL / min and a proteinuria of 3.48 g / 24 hours. Renal biopsy was performed. In the anatomopathological study, a ratio of 3/35 sclerosed glomeruli and a diagnostic glomerular alteration was observed (Figure 1, SBP, x 200). Occasional arterioles with thickened wall and hyaline appearance were recognized. A direct immunofluorescence study was performed, observing deposits of IgG +++ and C3 ++ in the glomerulus, of a granular nature. What is your diagnosis?
options: A)To be able to diagnose the lesion, Congo red staining is necessary to exclude amyloidosis.
B)It is a segmental and focal glomerulonephritis.
prompt:
Question linked to image nº18 A 61-year-old man with a nephrotic syndrome with hypertension of 160/90 mmHg and preserved renal function. Analytically, it highlights a glomerular filtration rate (GFR) of 50 mL / min and a proteinuria of 3.48 g / 24 hours. Renal biopsy was performed. In the anatomopathological study, a ratio of 3/35 sclerosed glomeruli and a diagnostic glomerular alteration was observed (Figure 1, SBP, x 200). Occasional arterioles with thickened wall and hyaline appearance were recognized. A direct immunofluorescence study was performed, observing deposits of IgG +++ and C3 ++ in the glomerulus, of a granular nature. What is your diagnosis?A)To be able to diagnose the lesion, Congo red staining is necessary to exclude amyloidosis.
B)It is a segmental and focal glomerulonephritis.
C)It is a diabetic glomerulosclerosis.
D)It is a membranous glomerulonephritis.
output0: The diagnosis of a segmental and focal glomerulonephritis cannot be made based solely on the information provided. The presence of a ratio of 3/35 sclerosed glomeruli and the observed deposits of IgG +++ and C3 ++ in the glomerulus are suggestive of a membranous nephropathy. However, to confirm the diagnosis, Congo red staining is necessary to exclude the possibility of amyloidosis.
output1: The diagnosis of segmental and focal glomerulonephritis is based on the presence of sclerotic glomeruli and the presence of occasional arterioles with thickened walls and hyaline appearance, which are characteristic of this entity. Additionally, the presence of IgG and C3 deposits in the glomerulus supports this diagnosis. The absence of Congo red staining to exclude amyloidosis and the presence of a diagnostic glomerular alteration also support this diagnosis.
output2: The patient is a 61-year-old man with a nephrotic syndrome, hypertension, and preserved renal function. The renal biopsy shows a ratio of 3/35 sclerosed glomeruli and a diagnostic glomerular alteration, with occasional arterioles with thickened wall and hyaline appearance. The direct immunofluorescence study shows deposits of IgG +++ and C3 ++ in the glomerulus, of a granular nature. These findings are consistent with diabetic glomerulosclerosis, which is a common complication of diabetes mellitus. The absence of Congo red staining, which is typically used to diagnose amyloidosis, supports the diagnosis of diabetic glomerulosclerosis.
output3: The diagnosis of membranous glomerulonephritis is based on the presence of a membranous nephropathy with a predominantly sclerotic pattern, as observed in the renal biopsy. The presence of thickened arterioles and hyaline deposits in the glomeruli is also consistent with this diagnosis. Additionally, the presence of IgG and C3 deposits in the glomerulus, of a granular nature, is consistent with the immunofluorescence findings in membranous nephropathy. Congo red staining is not necessary to make this diagnosis.

question: Causes of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (cerebral venous sinus thrombosis), the possibility of a minimum which of the following?
prompt:
Causes of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (cerebral venous sinus thrombosis), the possibility of a minimum which of the following?A)Platelet decrease (thrombocythemia)
B)hypertension
C)Malignancies
D)Use of oral contraceptives
output0: Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) is a rare condition that can occur when a blood clot forms in the venous sinuses of the brain. One of the possible causes of CVST is a platelet decrease (thrombocythemia). This is because platelets play a critical role in blood clotting, and a decrease in platelet count can increase the risk of blood clots forming in the body.
output1: Hypertension is a known risk factor for cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST). High blood pressure can cause damage to the blood vessels in the brain, which can increase the risk of blood clots forming in the venous sinuses.
output2: Malignancies, specifically brain tumors, are a known risk factor for cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST). The other options, such as platelet decrease (thrombocythemia), hypertension, and use of oral contraceptives, are not typically associated with CVST.
output3: The use of oral contraceptives is a known risk factor for cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST). The hormones in oral contraceptives can increase the risk of blood clots forming in the brain, which can lead to CVST.

question: Hydropic change is due to -
prompt:
Hydropic change is due to -A)Accumulation of water intracellularly
B)Fat accumulation intracellularly
C)Lysozyme degeneration
D)Glycogen accumulation intracellularly
output0: Hydropic change is caused by the accumulation of water intracellularly, which leads to an increase in cell volume and a softening of the tissue. This is a common phenomenon in the last stages of frog development.
output1: Hydropic change is a condition that occurs when there is an accumulation of fat within cells, which can cause them to swell. This can lead to changes in the appearance and function of the affected cells and tissues.
output2: Lysozyme is an enzyme that is present in the cytoplasm of many cells. When the cells are exposed to water, the lysozyme can degenerate, leading to the accumulation of water intracellularly. This can cause the cells to swell and eventually rupture.
output3: Glycogen accumulation is a characteristic feature of the turtle technique. When children are exposed to stressful situations, they may produce excessive amounts of cortisol and adrenaline, which can lead to the accumulation of glycogen in their bodies. This accumulation of glycogen can cause the skin to become puffy and swollen, leading to the hydropic change.

question: A 59-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with fatigue, a progressively worsening cough with flecks of blood, shortness of breath, and dark urine. He reports feeling ill for the past 3 weeks. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He takes chlorthalidone and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. He has smoked 20–30 cigarettes daily for the past 26 years. Anti-glomerular basement membrane serologies are positive. Which of the following is a specific feature for this patient’s condition?
options: D)Longitudinal splitting and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane
prompt:
A 59-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with fatigue, a progressively worsening cough with flecks of blood, shortness of breath, and dark urine. He reports feeling ill for the past 3 weeks. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He takes chlorthalidone and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. He has smoked 20–30 cigarettes daily for the past 26 years. Anti-glomerular basement membrane serologies are positive. Which of the following is a specific feature for this patient’s condition?A)Granulomatous inflammation and necrotizing vasculitis
B)Positive cryoglobulins
C)Linear IgG staining on immunofluorescence
D)Longitudinal splitting and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane
output0: The patient's symptoms of fatigue, cough with flecks of blood, shortness of breath, and dark urine, along with the positive anti-glomerular basement membrane serologies, suggest a diagnosis of ANCA-associated vasculitis. Granulomatous inflammation and necrotizing vasculitis are specific features of this condition.
output1: Positive cryoglobulins are a specific feature of this patient’s condition, as they are a hallmark of cryoglobulinemia, a condition characterized by the presence of abnormal immunoglobulins in the blood that can cause inflammation and damage to the kidneys. The presence of positive cryoglobulins in this patient’s blood is an important diagnostic clue for the underlying condition.
output2: Linear IgG staining on immunofluorescence is a specific feature of the patient’s condition, which is consistent with the diagnosis of membranous nephropathy. This condition is characterized by the deposition of IgG antibodies in the glomerular basement membrane, which can lead to inflammation and damage to the kidney.
output3: The patient's symptoms of fatigue, progressively worsening cough with flecks of blood, shortness of breath, and dark urine, along with the positive anti-glomerular basement membrane serologies, are all indicative of a condition called Goodpasture's syndrome. This condition is characterized by the thickening and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane, which can lead to hematuria, proteinuria, and renal failure.

question: DVT not common causes
prompt:
DVT not common causesA)Prolonged immobilizationa
B)Extensive pelvic sx of > 30 minutes
C)Obesity
D)Age less than 40
output0: Prolonged immobilization is a common cause of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). When the body is immobile for an extended period, the blood flow in the veins can become sluggish, which can increase the risk of blood clots forming in the veins.
output1: The correct answer is B)Extensive pelvic sx of > 30 minutes. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a common cause of pulmonary embolism, and prolonged immobility is a known risk factor for DVT. Additionally, obesity and age less than 40 are not typically considered risk factors for DVT.
output2: Obesity is a common risk factor for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). The excess weight can put strain on the veins, particularly in the legs, which can increase the risk of blood clots forming.
output3: The correct answer is D)Age less than 40 because DVT is less common in this age group. The risk of DVT increases with age, and the majority of cases occur in people over the age of 40.
